result.markdown:
# Box plots {.unnumbered} ::: {.callout-tip appearance='simple' icon=false} ***This graph is largely complete and just needs final proof reading.*** ::: :::: {.callout-note collapse="false" icon=false} ## Graph info ::: {style="font-size: 1.25em; color: #007bff;"} **Should I use this graph?** :::
::: {.cell layout-align="right"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](box_plots_files/figure-html/full_code_display-1.png){fig-align='right' width=60% height=60%} ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #007bff;"} **This graph requires:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 1.05em; color: #fa7b3c;"} **✅ a numeric (continuous) variable** ::: :::: ## Description Box plots (sometimes called box-and-whisker plots) use position, lines (vertical and horizontal), and points to convey a collection of summary statistics in a single graph. ## Getting set up :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Packages ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **PACKAGES:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Install packages. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} install.packages("palmerpenguins") library(palmerpenguins) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ### Data ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **DATA:** ::: ::: {.column-margin} ![Artwork by Allison Horst](www/lter_penguins.png){fig-align="right" width="100%" height="100%"} ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} We'll be using the `penguins` data from `palmerpenguins`. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} penguins <- palmerpenguins::penguins glimpse(penguins) #> Rows: 344 #> Columns: 8 #> $ species Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, Adelie, … #> $ island Torgersen, Torgersen, Torgersen,… #> $ bill_length_mm 39.1, 39.5, 40.3, NA, 36.7, 39.3… #> $ bill_depth_mm 18.7, 17.4, 18.0, NA, 19.3, 20.6… #> $ flipper_length_mm 181, 186, 195, NA, 193, 190, 181… #> $ body_mass_g 3750, 3800, 3250, NA, 3450, 3650… #> $ sex male, female, female, NA, female… #> $ year 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 2007, 20… ``` ::: ::: :::: ## The grammar :::: {.panel-tabset} ### Code ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **CODE:** ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Create labels with `labs()` Initialize the graph with `ggplot()` and provide `data` - Assign a blank character string (`""`) to the `x` axis in `labs()` Map `flipper_length_mm` to the `y` axis and an empty string (`""`) to the `x` axis Add the `geom_boxplot()` layer ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code code-fold="show"} labs_boxplot <- labs( title = "Adult foraging penguins", subtitle = "Distribution of flipper length", x = "", y = "Flipper length (millimeters)") ggp2_boxplot <- ggplot(data = penguins, aes(x = "", y = flipper_length_mm)) + geom_boxplot() ggp2_boxplot + labs_boxplot ``` ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 1.10em; color: #1e83c8;"} **GRAPH:** ::: ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](box_plots_files/figure-html/create_graph_box-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: :::: ### More Info Below we provide more information on interpreting Box plots. :::: {.panel-tabset} ### `movies` data ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} We'll use the `ggplot2movies::movies` data to create a box plot for movie `length` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} install.packages("ggplot2movies") library(ggplot2movies) library(ggplot2) ``` ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Filter `ggplot2movies::movies` to only include films after the made after `2000`, and remove missing values from `mpaa` and `budget` ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ```{.r .cell-code} movies_box <- ggplot2movies::movies |> dplyr::filter(year > 2000 & mpaa != "" & !is.na(budget)) head(movies_box) ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
````` ::: ::: ::: ### Graph ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Below we create a box plot of the `length` variable using the methods described above: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell .column-page-inset-right layout-nrow="1"} ```{.r .cell-code} labs_boxplot <- labs( title = "IMDB Movie information and user ratings", y = "Movie length (min)", x = "") ggp2_boxplot <- ggplot(data = movies_box, aes(x = " ", y = length)) + geom_boxplot() ggp2_boxplot + labs_boxplot ``` ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](box_plots_files/figure-html/more_create_graph_box-1.png){width=576} ::: ::: ::: ### Interpret ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The table below shows the 25th percentile, the median, the 75th percentile, the IQR, and a histogram of the `length` variable from the `movies_box` dataset. ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.75em;"} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
25th Median 75th IQR Histogram
92 100 113 21 ▁▇▅▁▁
````` ::: ::: ::: ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} The figure below displays how each element in the box plot represents each of the statistics using lines and points. ::: :::: {.column-margin} ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} In `ggplot2`, values that fall more than 1.5 times the IQR are displayed as individual points (aka outliers). The lines extending from the bottom and top of the main box represent the last non-outlier value in the distribution. ::: :::: ![](www/boxplot-diagram.png){fig-align="center" width="80%" height="80%"} ### Compare ::: {style="font-size: 0.85em;"} Compare the `geom_point()`, `geom_freqpoly()`, `geom_histogram()`, and `geom_density()` graphs of `length` from `movie_box` below to the `geom_boxplot()`: ::: ![](www/boxplot-comparisons.png){fig-align="center" width="85%" height="85%"} ::::
